verses.text: These are the \f + \fr 25:1 \ft Possibly genuine, q. d. beyond doubt.\f*miscellaneous instructions of Solomon, which the friends of Ezekias king of Judea copied out.
The glory of God conceals a matter: but the glory of a king honours business.
Heaven is high, and earth is deep, and a king's heart is unsearchable.
Beat the drossy silver, and it shall be made entirely pure.
Slay the ungodly from before the king, and his throne shall prosper in righteousness.
Be not boastful in the presence of the king, and remain not in the places of princes;
for \add it is\add* better for thee that it should be said, Come up to me, than that \add one\add* should humble thee in the presence of the prince; speak of that which thine eyes have seen.
Get not suddenly into a quarrel, lest thou repent at last.
Whenever thy friend shall reproach thee, retreat backward, despise \add him\add* not;
lest thy friend continue to reproach thee, so thy quarrel and enmity shall not depart, but shall be to thee like death.
\add As\add* a golden apple in a necklace of sardius, so \add is it\add* to speak a \add wise\add* word.
In an ear-ring of gold a precious sardius is also set; \add so is\add* a wise word to an obedient ear.
As a fall of snow in the time of harvest is good against heat, so a faithful messenger \add refreshes\add* those that send him; for he helps the souls of his employers.
As winds and clouds and rains are most evident \add objects\add*, so is he that boasts of a false gift.
In long-suffering is prosperity to kings, and a soft tongue breaks the bones.
Having found honey, eat \add only\add* what is enough, lest haply thou be filled, and vomit it up.
Enter sparingly into thy friend's house, lest he be satiated with thy company, and hate thee.
\add As\add* a club, and a dagger, and a pointed arrow, so also is a man who bears false witness against his friend.
The way of the wicked and the foot of the transgressor shall perish in an evil day.
As vinegar is bad for a sore, so trouble befalling the body afflicts the heart.
If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink;
for so doing thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the Lord shall reward thee \add with\add* good.
The north wind raises clouds; so an impudent face provokes the tongue.
\add It is\add* better to dwell on a corner of the roof, than with a railing woman in an open house.
As cold water is agreeable to a thirsting soul, so is a good message from a land far off.
As if one should stop a well, and corrupt a spring of water, so \add is it\add* unseemly for a righteous man to fall before an ungodly man.
\add It is\add* not good to eat much honey; but it is right to honour venerable sayings.
As a city whose walls are broken down, and which is unfortified, so is a man who does anything without counsel.
